channel.title: NPR Morning Edition
channel.description: Morning Edition takes listeners around the country and the world with multi-faceted stories and commentaries every weekday. Hosts Steve Inskeep, Leila Fadel, Michel Martin and A Mart√≠nez bring you the latest breaking news and features to prepare you for the day.

item.title: Supreme Court upholds state bans on transgender care for minors
item.description: At issue was a Tenneessee law that bars minors from accessing gender-affirming care as they transition genders.

item.title: NYC comptroller arrested by federal agents at immigration court
item.description: New York City Comptroller Brad Lander, who is also a mayoral candidate, was arrested and detained for several hours on Tuesday after he tried to escort a man out of a routine immigration hearing.

item.title: What it's like in Iran as the conflict with Israel continues
item.description: NPR speaks with Setareh Sadeqi, assistant professor at Tehran University, about how Iranians are experiencing the conflict with Israel and what Iran hopes to achieve.

item.title: How President Trump is responding to the conflict between Iran and Israel
item.description: President Trump once distanced himself from Israel's military action in Iran. Now he's taking some ownership, and he's pushing back against political allies who oppose U.S. involvement.

item.title: Morning news brief
item.description: How Trump has responded to the Iran-Israel conflict, U.S. intelligence and Israel differ on status of Iran's nuclear program, immigration raids continue as Trump administration sends mixed messages.

item.title: A look at the 'golden share' agreement in the U.S. Steel-Nippon Steel partnership
item.description: NPR speaks with Todd Tucker, director of industrial policy and trade at the Roosevelt Institute, about the Trump administration's role in the U.S. Steel-Nippon Steel partnership.

item.title: Author and domestic abuse survivor Leslie Morgan Steiner discusses Sean Combs' trial
item.description: Leslie Morgan Steiner, author of a best-selling memoir on surviving domestic abuse, offers her perspective on the trial of hip-hop mogul Sean "Diddy" Combs.

item.title: Some families along U.S. border cross into Mexico to save money on grocery shopping
item.description: Inflation has fallen slightly but prices at the grocery store are still higher than they were before the pandemic. Along the U.S. southern border, some families find savings by shopping in Mexico.

item.title: NPR and PBS FRONTLINE investigate why storm recovery efforts can get bogged down
item.description: Climate-related storms are becoming more frequent and severe. NPR and PBS FRONTLINE investigate the forces keeping communities from building back in a way that protects them from the next storm.

item.title: What 1,200 miles on a paddleboard taught a writer about 'blue space'
item.description: Author Dan Rubinstein paddled from Ottawa to New York City and back to understand how being near water benefits people. His book is called "Water Borne."
